Completeness and relevance

A high-quality decision requires information that is:

Relevant

Directly tied to the policy question

Includes alternatives and tradeoffs

Clearly connected to the stated goals

Complete

Includes fiscal, legal, operational, personnel, and community impact

Avoids cherry-picking

Covers both short- and long-term consequences

Appropriately summarized

Decision-makers receive synthesized, digestible material

Not buried in raw data dumps or irrelevant documents

Choice architecture

A decision is low quality if:

Only one option was presented

Alternatives were ignored or discouraged

Comparison was superficial or missing

High-quality decisions:

Articulate multiple courses of action

Explicitly compare benefits, costs, and consequences

Identify the option rejected and why
